journal-title-group.journal-title: Quarterly Journal of Business and Economics

publisher.publisher-name: College of Business Administration of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln

title-group.article-title: A Non-Tax Cause for the January Effect? Evidence from Early Data

abstract.p: This paper examines the January effect using returns generated from the Cowles Industrial Index. The database cover 1871-1937. January returns are high relative to other monthly returns throughout this period. Implementation of the U.S. income tax divides the data into pre-tax and post-tax periods. The January effect is as strong in the pre-tax period as in the post-tax period; therefore, some non-tax factor influences the January effect. The paper also compares returns for the Cowles and Dow Jones Indexes for 1897-1937. Since the broad-based Cowles Index has a stronger January effect, a small-firm influence exists in the January effect during 1871-1937.
